profileText: A Delegate from North Carolina; born near Rock Church, Cecil County, Md., December 13, 1742; pursued classical studies; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Mecklenburg County, N.C. in 1763; also engaged in surveying; moved to Rowan (now Iredell) County; member of the Provincial Congress in 1775; aide to General Rutherford in the Indian campaign in 1776 and was one of four commissioners appointed by Governor Caswell to form a treaty with the Indians in 1777; delegate to the convention in Halifax in 1776 and helped to frame the first constitution of the state; Member of the Continental Congress 1779-1781; member of the state house of representatives in 1781 and 1782; died near Statesville, Iredell County, N.C., on July 1, 1818; interment in Snow Creek Graveyard.

researchRecord.name: In the Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection, 1780-1781, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers of William Sharpe contain a financial account (1780 Feb. 8) for North Carolina and typewritten a transcript of a letter (1781 Apr. 7) from William Sharpe to General Nathanael Greene commenting on hardships faced by the Continental Army.

researchRecord.name: In the Henry Laurens Papers, 1777-1792, 3 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers include a letter from Thomas Burke, William Sharpe, and Samuel Johnston asking Henry Laurens to support their suggestion that the British Navy be attacked from the coast of North Carolina.
